data.text:
Ending this thread on "Countdown" because it's in my top five Bey songs. The single demonstrates her ability to thread together six or seven song ideas into a single pop bop that no other artist could do but Bey just acts like it's no biggie. 

https://t.co/bTXLutXo5r

@SterlingSimmon6 Tbh, that's almost every day in my class! When I was at Bey's concert last week, there were three 8th graders (I teach 9th grade) from the school I teach at sitting directly behind me. They're in all my pics. They saw me (try to) dance and sing along!
I could go on and on and on. I'm gonna post two of my favorite Lemonade pieces instead: https://t.co/8o5XrTiSUv
@CodyMillerELA So you are going to find a way to talk her up in class tomorrow, right? Like that’s gonna be a thing, right?

If Beyoncé released an Instagram photo right now, then we'd have 1,403,920 think pieces about it in an hour. Who else has that command of popular culture? Bey doesn't have her finger on the zeitgeist. Bey is the zeitgeist.

Beyoncé doesn't care about radio hits and hasn't in a minute ("Radio says speed it up, I just go slow"). Yet, every single thing she does ends up being a hit. Folx wanna talk about Shakespeare adding to the lexicon? Please. Check Bey's discography.

Rock music criticism as a genre is overwhelming run by cishetero white men, who often ignore how the genre was formed by Black women. Same for country music criticism. Beyoncé's Lemonade was a counternarrative to the dominant story of the genres of rock and country.

Beyoncé is in her own stratosphere. She bends pop culture to her will. Her catalogue - especially everything after her eponymous album - acts as a type of musical ethnography, in which she weaves together often ignored history into the present.

Nearly every single time I bring up the need to rethink the canon, someone pulls some, "Name a more important writer than X" nonsense where X is usually Shakespeare or Faulkner. 

My eternal response: "Easy. Beyoncé."
